pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
Revelation per f2f:

* Every `//model/frame` needs `@affixed_to`, and `frame/pose[@frame]` should resolve by default to this frame.
* If we permit `//link/frame`, it complicates scoping rules \(per below discussion\), because they’re not as powerful \(limited semantics\). It also adds edges to `//link/frame[@affixed_to]`.

So maybe just permit only `//model/frame` and \(maybe\) `//world/frame`
content.html:
Revelation per f2f:

  • Every //model/frame needs @affixed_to, and frame/pose[@frame] should resolve by default to this frame.
  • If we permit //link/frame, it complicates scoping rules (per below discussion), because they’re not as powerful (limited semantics). It also adds edges to //link/frame[@affixed_to].

So maybe just permit only //model/frame and (maybe) //world/frame

content.raw: If it's useful, then a relevant example would help communicate that. I assume this means a model that has `<frame>` tags but no `<link>`s? My first guess is that a model with no links is just attached to the world. We use `<joint>` to express parent/child relationships between links; if we aren't using the `affixed_to` attribute for frames, maybe we would need something other way to affix a frame to a link?
content.html: If it's useful, then a relevant example would help communicate that. I assume this means a model that has <frame> tags but no <link>s? My first guess is that a model with no links is just attached to the world. We use <joint> to express parent/child relationships between links; if we aren't using the affixed_to attribute for frames, maybe we would need something other way to affix a frame to a link?

pull_request.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
I think it would be useful if the meaning of `pose[@frame]` is consistent across the board. Right now, it means "affixed_to" in `//model/frame/pose[@frame]` but means "expressed w.r.t" (and NOT affixed to) in `//link/frame[@frame]`, `/model/pose[@frame]`, `//link/pose[@frame]`, and `//include/pose[@frame]`. My suggestion would be to removed the "affixed_to" semantics from the pose tag and put it in the frame tag with an extra attribute. For example we can do:

```xml
<model name="M">
  <frame name="F1" affixed_to="L1">
     <pose frame="L1">{X_L1F1}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L1 and pose expressed w.r.t L1 -->
  </frame>
  <frame name="F2" affixed_to="L2">
     <pose>{X_MF2}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L2 but pose expressed w.r.t M -->
  </frame>
  
  <link name="L1"/>
   <link name="L2"/>
</model>
```

I realize there is an exception with `//link/frame` in that it can't have an `affixed_to` attribute, but, in my mind, that's easier to reason about and remember.
content.html:
I think it would be useful if the meaning of pose[@frame] is consistent across the board. Right now, it means "affixed_to" in //model/frame/pose[@frame] but means "expressed w.r.t" (and NOT affixed to) in //link/frame[@frame], /model/pose[@frame], //link/pose[@frame], and //include/pose[@frame]. My suggestion would be to removed the "affixed_to" semantics from the pose tag and put it in the frame tag with an extra attribute. For example we can do:

<model name="M">
  <frame name="F1" affixed_to="L1">
     <pose frame="L1">{X_L1F1}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L1 and pose expressed w.r.t L1 -->
  </frame>
  <frame name="F2" affixed_to="L2">
     <pose>{X_MF2}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L2 but pose expressed w.r.t M -->
  </frame>

  <link name="L1"/>
   <link name="L2"/>
</model>

I realize there is an exception with //link/frame in that it can't have an affixed_to attribute, but, in my mind, that's easier to reason about and remember.

pull_request.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw:
I'm rewriting your example slightly to clarify that `L1` is connected by `J1`

~~~
<link name="P"/>
<joint name="J1" type="fixed">
  <parent>P</parent>
  <child>L1</child>
</joint>
<link name="L1">
  <frame name="F1">
    <pose frame="J1">...</pose> <!-- Accessing "J1"  here appears to be a violation of the scoping rules -->
  </frame>
</link>
~~~
content.html:
I'm rewriting your example slightly to clarify that L1 is connected by J1

<link name="P"/>
<joint name="J1" type="fixed">
  <parent>P</parent>
  <child>L1</child>
</joint>
<link name="L1">
  <frame name="F1">
    <pose frame="J1">...</pose> <!-- Accessing "J1"  here appears to be a violation of the scoping rules -->
  </frame>
</link>

~~~

should it say: `but pose expressed w.r.t M` (ie `L2` -> `M`)
content.html:
@azeey in the following line of your example:

     <pose>{X_MF2}</pose> <!-- Affixed to L2 but pose expressed w.r.t L2 -->

should it say: but pose expressed w.r.t M (ie L2 -> M)

content.raw:
My concern with having an implicit frame is that when said frame is used in `//link/frame/pose[@frame]` it can give the impression that the scoping rules are being violated.

```
<link name="L1">
   <frame name="F1">
       <pose frame="J1">...</pose> <!-- Accessing "J1"  here appears to be a violation of the scoping rules -->
   </frame>
</link>
<joint name="J1"/>
```
content.html:
My concern with having an implicit frame is that when said frame is used in //link/frame/pose[@frame] it can give the impression that the scoping rules are being violated.

<link name="L1">
   <frame name="F1">
       <pose frame="J1">...</pose> <!-- Accessing "J1"  here appears to be a violation of the scoping rules -->
   </frame>
</link>
<joint name="J1"/>

pull_request.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw: This doesn't make sense to me either. There is a valid question here: to which link is the model frame affixed? But I'm not sure "parent link determined by joint connections" makes sense; what if you have a model with a single link and no joints? I feel like this is where the canonical link concept is used in gazebo. Is that what you want to formalize here?
content.html: This doesn't make sense to me either. There is a valid question here: to which link is the model frame affixed? But I'm not sure "parent link determined by joint connections" makes sense; what if you have a model with a single link and no joints? I feel like this is where the canonical link concept is used in gazebo. Is that what you want to formalize here?

content.raw:
I'm not sure if we need explicit joint frames, but the most relevant use case I can think of is `<joint><sensor type="forcetorque">`, which has already added some custom elements to try to deal with frames:

* http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=sensor#sensor_force_torque
* https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/sdf6/sdf/1.6/forcetorque.sdf
content.html:
I'm not sure if we need explicit joint frames, but the most relevant use case I can think of is <joint><sensor type="forcetorque">, which has already added some custom elements to try to deal with frames:

  • http://sdformat.org/spec?ver=1.6&elem=sensor#sensor_force_torque
  • https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/src/sdf6/sdf/1.6/forcetorque.sdf

pull_request.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: Suggested semantics to handle maximal coordinates

content.raw: `//world/frame` is a nice way to indicate that a frame is fixed to the world. Seems like it could be nice to have.
content.html: //world/frame is a nice way to indicate that a frame is fixed to the world. Seems like it could be nice to have.
